title: The Tale of the Bamboo Princess
author: Traditional

content.text: Once upon a time, in a quiet village nestled between misty mountains and whispering bamboo groves, there lived an old bamboo cutter named Taketori no Okina.
He was a kind and gentle man, known far and wide for his skill in crafting baskets and flutes from the slender bamboo stalks.
Though he and his wife, Ona, had lived many years together, their home was filled with loneliness, for they had no children to brighten their days.
One evening, as the sun dipped below the hills and painted the sky with hues of pink and gold, Taketori no Okina walked into the bamboo grove to gather stalks for his work.
The air was still, and the only sounds were the rustling of leaves and the distant call of a nightingale.
As he reached for a particularly tall and graceful stalk, he noticed something strange—a soft, golden glow emanating from within its hollow center.
Curious, he split the bamboo open with his knife.
To his astonishment, inside sat a tiny, radiant child, no larger than his thumb, with skin as pale as moonlight and hair as dark as the night sky.
She smiled up at him, her eyes shimmering like stars, and in that moment, Taketori no Okina knew she was no ordinary child.
He carefully lifted her from the bamboo and cradled her in his hands.
"Who are you, little one?" he whispered, his heart swelling with wonder.
The child did not speak, but her smile seemed to say, Take me home.
Without hesitation, Taketori no Okina wrapped the tiny girl in his sleeve and hurried back to his cottage.
When he showed her to Ona, his wife gasped in amazement.
"She is a gift from the heavens!" Ona exclaimed, her eyes filling with tears of joy.
They decided then and there to raise the child as their own, naming her Kaguya-hime, the Princess of the Radiant Night, for her beauty was as luminous as the moon.
From that day forward, strange and wondrous things began to happen.
Every time Taketori no Okina cut down a stalk of bamboo, he would find a small nugget of gold nestled inside.
The gold piled up quickly, and soon, the humble bamboo cutter and his wife became wealthy beyond their wildest dreams.
But no matter how much gold they found, their greatest treasure was Kaguya-hime herself.
As the years passed, Kaguya-hime grew with astonishing speed.
In just three months, she had become a young woman of unearthly beauty, her presence filling their home with light.
News of her grace and kindness spread throughout the land, and soon, suitors from far and wide came to ask for her hand in marriage.
Five noblemen, each more determined than the last, arrived at the cottage, each declaring their undying love for her.
Kaguya-hime, however, was not like other girls.
Though she was grateful for their affection, she had no desire to marry.
But she did not wish to hurt their feelings, so she devised a plan.
To each suitor, she gave an impossible task, promising to marry the one who could fulfill it.

To the first nobleman, the Prince of Ise, she said, "Bring me the stone begging bowl of the Buddha from India." To the second, the Minister of the Right, she asked for a jeweled branch from the mythical island of Horai.
The third, the Captain of the Imperial Guard, was tasked with finding the robe of the fire-rat from China.
The fourth, the Middle Counselor, was to retrieve a colored jewel from the neck of a dragon.
And the fifth, the Major Counselor, was to bring her a cowry shell born from a swallow’s nest.
The suitors, eager to win her hand, set off on their quests.
But each one, in turn, failed in their task—some through trickery, others through sheer impossibility.
The Prince of Ise, for example, tried to pass off a fake stone bowl, only for Kaguya-hime to see through his deception.
The Minister of the Right had a jeweled branch crafted by the finest artisans, but when the craftsmen came demanding payment, his lie was exposed.
One by one, the suitors returned in shame, their dreams of marrying the Bamboo Princess shattered.
Even the Emperor himself heard of Kaguya-hime’s beauty and sent for her.
When he saw her, he was struck by her grace and begged her to become his wife.
But Kaguya-hime, though flattered, refused him as well. "I am not of this world," she told him gently.
"I cannot stay here forever."  The Emperor, though saddened, respected her wishes and left her in peace.
But as the years passed, Kaguya-hime grew quieter and more sorrowful.
She would often gaze at the moon with tears in her eyes, as if longing for something far beyond the earth.
One evening, as the autumn moon rose full and bright in the sky, Kaguya-hime called Taketori no Okina and Ona to her side.
Her voice trembled as she spoke.
"Dear Father, dear Mother, the time has come for me to return to where I belong.
I am not of this world—I am a child of the moon, sent here as a test of your kindness.
The gold you found was a gift from my people, but now, my time on earth is ending."  Taketori no Okina and Ona wept bitterly, begging her to stay.
"We cannot bear to lose you!" they cried. But Kaguya-hime shook her head sadly. "I must go.
But I will never forget your love."  On the night of the next full moon, a procession of celestial beings descended from the sky, their robes shimmering like silver threads.
They came to take Kaguya-hime home.
The Emperor, hearing of her departure, sent his guards to stop them, but the moon people were too powerful.
Kaguya-hime, dressed in a robe of feathers, turned to her earthly parents one last time.
"Take this," she said, handing them a letter and a vial of the Elixir of Life.
"If you drink this, you will live forever.
But I know you will not, for your love is too great to be parted from the earth." She then gave them a small box.
"Inside is a robe that will protect you from sorrow.
Wear it when you miss me."  With tears streaming down her face, Kaguya-hime stepped into the celestial carriage.
As it rose into the sky, she tossed the vial of elixir back to the Emperor’s guards, for she knew that immortality was not meant for mortals.
The carriage disappeared into the moon’s glow, leaving behind only the echo of her sorrowful song.
Taketori no Okina and Ona mourned deeply, but they cherished the memories of their time with Kaguya-hime.
The Emperor, heartbroken, ordered the letter and the elixir to be taken to the highest mountain in the land and burned, so that the smoke might carry his love to the heavens.
And so, the mountain was named Fuji, which means "immortal," for it was said that the smoke of the Emperor’s love still rises to this day.
And though Kaguya-hime was gone, her story lived on—a tale of love, loss, and the fleeting beauty of life, whispered through the bamboo groves and passed down from generation to generation.
